section.title: Indentation
section.p: Indentation is four spaces -- no tabs. Only file types that absolutely require tabs (e.g. `Makefile`) may use them.

section.title: Line Length
section.p: With the exception of documentation code, no line of any code or test file shall exceed 132 characters. If a line break is required, then it shall be after the first function parenthesis:
If a conditional, then after a completed conditional, for example:

section.title: Function Comments
section.p: Comments for extern functions should be included in the .h file. Comments for static functions and implementation-specific notes for extern functions (i.e., not of interest to the general user) should be included in the .c file.

section.title: Variables
section.p: Variable names use camel case with the first letter lower-case.

list.list-item: stanzaName - the name of the stanza
nameIdx - loop variable for iterating through a list of names

section.p: Variable names should be descriptive. Avoid i, j, etc.

section.title: Types
section.p: Type names use camel case with the first letter upper case:

section.title: Constants
section.p: #define constants should be all caps with _ separators.
The value should be aligned at column 69 whenever possible.
This type of constant should mostly be used for strings. Use enums whenever possible for integer constants.
String constants can be declared using the STRING_STATIC() macro for local strings and STRING_EXTERN() for strings that will be externed for use in other modules.

Enum elements follow the same case rules as variables. They are strongly typed so this shouldn't present any confusion.
Note the comma after the last element. This reduces diff churn when new elements are added.

section.title: Macros
section.p: Macro names should be upper-case with underscores between words. Macros (except simple constants) should be avoided whenever possible as they make code less clear and test coverage harder to measure.

To avoid conflicts, variables in a macro will be named [macro name]_[var name], e.g. TEST_RESULT_resultExpected. Variables that need to be accessed in wrapped code should be provided accessor macros.
Variadic functions are an exception to the capitalization rule.

section.title: Begin / End
section.p: Use Begin / End for names rather than Start / Finish, etc.

section.title: New / Free
section.p: Use New / Free for constructors and destructors rather than Create / Destroy, etc.

section.title: Braces
section.p: C allows braces to be excluded for a single statement. However, braces should be used when the control statement (if, while, etc.) spans more than one line or the statement to be executed spans more than one line.
No braces needed:
Braces needed:

Braces should be added to switch statement cases that have a significant amount of code. As a general rule of thumb, if the code block in the case is large enough to have blank lines and/or multiple comments then it should be enclosed in braces.

section.title: Hints, Warnings, and Errors
section.p: Hints are to be formatted with capitalized HINT: followed by a space and a sentence. The sentence shall only begin with a capital letter if the first word is an acronym (e.g. TLS) or a proper name (e.g. PostgreSQL). The sentence must end with a period, question mark or exclamation point as appropriate.
Warning and errors shall be lowercase with the exceptions for proper names and acronyms and end without punctuation.

section.title: Data Types
section.p: Don't get exotic - use the simplest type that will work.
Use int or unsigned int for general cases. int will be at least 32 bits. When not using int use one of the types defined in common/type.h.

section.title: Macros
section.p: Don't use a macro when a function could be used instead. Macros make it hard to measure code coverage.

section.title: Objects
section.p: Object-oriented programming is used extensively. The object pointer is always referred to as this.
An object can expose internal struct members by defining a public struct that contains the members to be exposed and using inline functions to get/set the members.

section.title: Uncoverable Code
section.p: The uncoverable keyword marks code that can never be covered. For instance, a function that never returns because it always throws an error. Uncoverable code should be rare to non-existent outside the common libraries and test code.
section.code-block: } // {uncoverable - function throws error so never returns}
section.p: Subsequent code that is uncoverable for the same reason is marked with // {+uncoverable}.

section.title: Uncovered Code
section.p: Marks code that is not tested for one reason or another. This should be kept to a minimum and an excuse given for each instance.
section.code-block: exit(EXIT_FAILURE); // {uncovered - test harness does not support non-zero exit}
section.p: Subsequent code that is uncovered for the same reason is marked with `// {+uncovered}`.
